wikipedia_page.main: William Thomas Braithwaite (14 April 1844 – 22 January 1918) was a northern Irish businessman, freemason, and marksman. He was the co-founder of the public house chain of Braithwaite & McCann which eventually owned 15 bars and pubs in Belfast. In 1906 he made a large donation of paintings to the Belfast Municipal Museum and Art Gallery, now known as the Ulster Museum.

response: The conversion to a pub was designed by William Thomas Braithwaite, who was the co-founder of the Braithwaite & McCann public house chain . The Hatfield House was their first pub, but by 1899 they also owned the Red Lion, also on the Ormeau Road, and the Garrick in Chichester Street. They expanded to acquire the Store Bar in Church Lane and the Ulster Tavern in Chichester Street, and eventually owned 15 bars and pubs in Belfast.The hidden history of Belfast pubs. Gary Law, Belfast Telegraph, 6 April 2002. Retrieved 13 January 2018.
